title: How to Make Coffee with a Drip Coffee Maker
description: Learn the simple, classic method for brewing a delicious pot of coffee using a standard automatic drip coffee maker. This tutorial will guide you through each step, from measuring beans to pouring the perfect cup.
tools_required: Whole coffee beans or pre-ground coffee

steps.title: Gather Your Equipment and Ingredients
steps.description: Before you begin, gather all your supplies. You will need your automatic drip coffee maker, a coffee filter that fits your machine, coffee beans or grounds, a measuring scoop, and fresh, cold water.
tips: Using filtered water can improve the taste of your coffee by removing chlorine and other impurities.
Ensure your coffee maker is clean before starting; old coffee oils can make your brew taste bitter.
steps.image_prompt: A photorealistic shot of a clean, modern kitchen counter with a stainless steel drip coffee maker, a bag of artisan coffee beans, a paper filter, a coffee scoop, and a glass water carafe neatly arranged. The scene is illuminated by bright, natural morning light from a window, creating soft shadows on the white marble countertop.

steps.title: Measure and Grind Your Coffee
steps.description: Measure your coffee. A good starting ratio is one to two tablespoons of ground coffee for every six ounces of water. If using whole beans, grind them to a medium consistency, similar to the texture of granulated sugar. If using pre-ground coffee, simply measure it out.
tips: For a stronger brew, use more coffee grounds. For a weaker brew, use less.
Grinding beans just before brewing provides the freshest, most flavorful coffee.
steps.image_prompt: A close-up, photorealistic image of hands pouring dark roasted coffee beans from a silver scoop into an electric burr grinder. The focus is sharp on the beans, with the clean kitchen background softly blurred. The lighting is bright and natural, highlighting the glossy texture of the beans.

steps.title: Place the Filter and Add Coffee Grounds
steps.description: Open the brew basket of your coffee maker. Place a coffee filter inside, ensuring it sits flat and is properly seated. Add your measured coffee grounds into the center of the filter, gently shaking the basket to level the grounds for an even extraction.
tips: If using a paper filter, you can briefly rinse it with hot water before adding the grounds to remove any papery taste.
steps.image_prompt: An overhead, slightly angled photorealistic shot showing a hand adding a scoop of medium-ground coffee into a white paper filter already placed inside the coffee maker's brew basket. The focus is on the dark coffee grounds contrasting with the white filter. The kitchen setting and natural lighting are consistent.

steps.title: Fill the Reservoir with Water
steps.description: Using the markings on the coffee carafe or a measuring cup, measure the desired amount of cold, fresh water. Pour the water directly into the coffee maker's water reservoir. Do not pour water over the coffee grounds in the brew basket.
warnings: Be careful not to overfill the water reservoir past the maximum fill line.
steps.image_prompt: A photorealistic side-view shot of a person pouring clear, fresh water from the glass coffee carafe into the water reservoir of the drip coffee maker. The water level markings on both the carafe and the machine are visible. The scene is brightly lit with natural morning light, creating a clean and appealing look.

steps.title: Start the Brewing Cycle
steps.description: Place the carafe back onto the warming plate, close the brew basket lid, and plug in the machine if it isn't already. Press the 'Start' or 'Brew' button to begin the brewing cycle. You should hear the machine start to heat the water and gurgle.
steps.image_prompt: A detailed, macro photorealistic shot of a finger pressing the illuminated 'Brew' button on a modern coffee maker. The button glows with a soft white light. The stainless steel finish of the machine reflects the bright kitchen environment. The focus is tight on the finger and button, emphasizing the action.

steps.title: Wait for the Brew to Finish
steps.description: The brewing process will take several minutes, depending on the amount of coffee you are making. Wait until the machine stops making noise and coffee is no longer dripping into the carafe. This ensures you get a full, properly extracted pot.
tips: Most machines have an auto-pause feature, but it's best to avoid removing the carafe mid-brew to prevent any potential overflow from the brew basket.
steps.image_prompt: A photorealistic image of the glass coffee carafe on the warming plate, now full of dark, rich coffee. Steam gently rises from the top of the carafe. The final drips of coffee are seen falling from the brew basket above. The morning light catches the steam and the glass, creating a warm and inviting atmosphere.

steps.title: Pour and Enjoy Your Coffee
steps.description: Once the brewing is complete, carefully remove the carafe from the warming plate. Pour the fresh coffee into your favorite mug. Add cream, sugar, or other flavorings as desired.
tips: Turn off the coffee maker's warming plate after serving to prevent the remaining coffee from developing a burnt taste.
warnings: The carafe and the coffee will be very hot. Handle with care.
The warming plate remains hot after brewing. Do not touch it.
steps.image_prompt: A beautiful, photorealistic action shot of hot coffee being poured from the glass carafe into a white ceramic mug. A wisp of steam rises from the mug. The background is the clean, bright kitchen, softly out of focus. The focus is sharp on the stream of coffee and the mug's rim.

safety_notes: Always handle the hot carafe and freshly brewed coffee with caution to prevent burns.
Be aware that the warming plate on the coffee maker stays hot during and after use.
Unplug the coffee maker when not in use for extended periods or when cleaning.
